title: Content rating "Low Maturity" is correct more ways than one….
comment: Multiple issues with this app on my Droid Turbo: * Audio will suddenly start playing again, long after I leave the app. So far the only way I've found to prevent this is to clear my playlist before I exit. * Very long load times, anywhere from 1-5 min before play starts regardless of network type (WiFi, 3G, 4G) * Playlist is more a play queue, I have to manually launch each segment of the show. * Inconsistent interaction with lock screen. Sometimes it pops up with a 'mini' player that I can (again) pause the playback after it does a random start-up, other times not so much. * Lack of settings/control - more options, especially around privacy would be nice.  I'm going to uninstall and wait till a more 'mature' app comes along…. nice first effort though.

title: As a way to find NPR shows, it's OK. As a media player, it's a train wreck.
comment: It's nice to have all my NPR shows in one place (as long as they're not more than a week old). It's just too bad that one place is this app. It's super clunky, it doesn't remember where you left off if you used any apps since the last time you used it, so long podcasts like Car Talk become a guessing game every time you start back up and try to figure out where you left off. It also, for some boggling reason, can't be controlled from the lock screen, so better just set it and forget it in your car, or you're probably going to die. Also, it can't store the podcast on your device, so if you have weak signal, you're just not going to advance to that next track.   If there was any other app that I could find to listen to my NPR podcasts, I would.

title: Note 3 problems
comment: I have an intermittent problem when I am listening to NPR on my Samsung Note 3. The taskbar flashes blue, and if I turn the screen off and turn it back on, I can use my phone for a brief second without unlocking it, but then I cannot actually unlock it. Sometimes the problem stops if I'm patient, other times I have to use my moment of usability to restart. So far I have not had any similar problems in other apps, so I think it is probably the NPR app.  I'm going to give the app 1 star because I am forced to give a rating to post the review and I want the creators of the app to take notice. In actuality, besides the bug I'm experiencing, it is a great app.

title: Website and App Syncing Needed!
comment: The app has evolved and delivers a much better experience than when I first downloaded it.  I have been able to listen to NPR program without much hassle and only intermittently experience playback issues or glitches.  I think that the app is becoming quite polished and I appreciate your dedication to updating the catalog of audio files by bringing more shows to the app.  One improvement that I would like to see is an integration between the website and your apps.  Sometimes I find myself browsing NPR and wishing I could continue a story on my mobile device at a later point if I am on the move.  The addition of a saved articles or read-it-later type functionality would be awesome.  Another key feature would be a unified playlist that syncs between app and our profiles on the website.   I like to stream your app in my car and it would be nice to add stories I am interested in from my computer and play them on my mobile device when I get into my car.  Currently, there does not appear to be any profile functionality on the mobile app.  Keep up the great work.  I really enjoy using this app as a source for news and culture.

title: New version running better
comment: Since my previous review, the app has improved greatly. I haven't noticed it skipping songs when buffering.  The big improvement I see is adding play/pause/skip to the lock screen when the app is playing. This also connects into bluetooth devices like the Jambox. I can pause my playlist or skip a story from my Jambox. Great addition!  A pet-peeve of mine with the app is the confirmation dialog every time I clear the playlist. I primarily use the app for news stories so I clear the playlist daily to remove outdated segments. A better solution would be to allow playing of all segments in a program (ie. Morning Edition) without adding them to the playlist.  If you added a way for me to donate to the app, via Paypal for instance, I would give!

I never know if it's going to work or not, but I keep using it on the off chance it does load right. I can add shows to my queue but whether or not it actually loads right is a gamble.   Sometimes I load things, give up, and a couple hours later it starts to play out of the blue (really nice when I'm in situations like a work meeting, and my phone starts blaring) I'm giving it 2 stars because when it works, it's so nice (I can listen to entire programs, which I like since I have a few I like to listen start to finish, like Morning Edition) but honestly NPR - with the constant reviews and complaints about how buggy this app is, you really need to get it together and fix it.   I've been using the NPR app for years now, and the revamp they did about 1.5 years ago ruined it. It'd be better if they just rolled it back to the older app than having people constantly battle the current one.

title: Spontaneously Running
comment: I am constantly stopping this app within running services. It runs spontaneously and will even start up when cleared from cached processes. Why NPR? I'm considering not re-installing it because it has become annoying. Such great programs, but a poorly designed app. 3 years I've used it off and on, and it's the same with little improvement. Running without request and a crummy interface. Why does adding a story to the queue automatically begin said story while I'm listening to another? I'm not building a queue so I can listen to the very last item I added. It also loses connection all of the time at random.

title: Wonderful!

title: Issues still not fixed
comment: I hoped that the new version would fix the persistent playback issues, but they're still present.  Simply trying to play the stories of Morning Edition or All Things Considered by tapping "Add all to playlist" and then starting the playlist results in random jumps to the next playlist item, starting in the middle of items, and skipping items altogether.  It's hard to believe that the developers are testing this app with much rigor.  I think some dogfooding would help expose its more frustrating issues.  I've experienced identical problems with the app on my Samsung GS II, Nexus 4, Nexus 7, and Nexus 5.  All that said, the app isn't totally worthless, so 2 stars instead of 1.  If NPR would let us get the MP3s for these programs from a regular RSS feed like some of the other shows, then I'd use my own podcast manager like Pocket Casts, but NPR still doesn't allow this for some reason.  I am a member of an NPR member station, but I would be totally willing to pay for this app if it were better and if the fee helped continue its development support.

comment: I had this app on my iPhone and loved it. When I got my new Android phone, it's one of the first apps I downloaded. However, I haven't been able to use it because audio won't work. It says "No audio" at the bottom of the screen. I've checked settings on both the phone and in the app and can't find the problem.   I love the NPR shows, and the app would make it easy to listen to them anytime. However, without functional audio, I can't rate it higher than one star.

title: Needs some help
comment: While the content offerings are great, the service is too unreliable as far as playback and streaming are concerned

title: Too biased
comment: Biased and unprofessional. If you want to receive accurate new, look elsewhere.

title: Very well done.
comment: Nice interface, listen to local radio station while still using NPR app for news is great. Offline caching options would be awesome. Great app, changed my life on every level.

title: Not ready for prime time
comment: Streaming has some glaring problems. I queued up several stories, and three of them started playing at the same time. The result was that as one story ended another would pick up mid stream.

title: Station streaming problems
comment: I use this app to look at news summaries and stream 10 minutes of news from morning edition. Live-stream freezes twice (avg) during that time. Happens on WiFi and 4g. Sometimes resumes in a couple of minutes, sometimes I have to restart the stream.

title: Good, needs tweak
comment: The app is good. Just allow the audio for the radio to come out of a standard Bluetooth headset, like one you would use for a phone. Then I can listen to the radio while my headset is on. I believe all you need to do is make the audio like a phone call and then it would work.

title: Really? No Landscape mode?
comment: Kind of a pain trying to use this on a tablet.

title: Keeps crashing
comment: I have this app installed on my new Eviant tablet and it crashes immediately upon opening.  I've uninstalled and re-installed several times to no avail.  I never had any issues with the iPhone version of this app, so I'm disappointed that it crashes repeatedly on the Android version.  Anyone else having this issue?

title: So annoying
comment: Takes forever to load stories. Freezes, crashes all  the time. Get something else to listen to NPR

title: One of my favorite apps
comment: Please bring back the remove only played stories option in the playlist. Also it jumps to the end of stories very often.

title: Developer Hassle
comment: I love NPR and the app but your developers did not turn off the app's log messages nor did they mark as attributed to the NPR app. This issue arose because I listened to NPR on my device while developing my own apps but the NPR app made my own development impossible because the app was sending so many messages to the Log that it made it impossible to see my own Log messages aiding in my troubleshooting. I had to listen to something else because of this much to my dismay. Since many of the messages aren't tagged as originating from the NPR app so they could not be filtered out thus relieving the issue.  "MLBCachedSource(218): readAt offset 12488744, size 4"  is spammed at an unbelievable rate while the NPR app is running.
Easy to use but playlist is jenky

title: PURE CRAP: September 2013
comment: This unbelievably lame app shuts off whenever there's an alert from another app, requiring a reconnect and re-buffering. THIS IS NOT THE OLDER VERSION, BUT THE LATEST AS OF JULY 1, 2013

title: Buffering problems
comment: Used to work great when streaming my local npr station on my way to work, but now I only get minutes before it buffers and forgets I was streaming anything. It used to be the best way to listen to WCBE in the car before I could receive it on terrestrial radio. I'm using the app on a Samsung Galaxy S4.

title: Unreliable
comment: I have downloaded this app a number of times over the years but I always get rid of it for the same reason. It frequently stops, pauses and buffers, especially after I receive any sort of notification on my Galaxy Note 2
Great app

title: Wonky and full of bugs

title: Love it
comment: Great app I love that you can queue radio shows and listen to many in a row while working or driving.

title: No!
comment: No thanks! to yet another app that finds need yo read my phone state and identity.  Trusted news source and great, thought- provoking reporting and stories.  But I will go back to the airwaves and bypass the data-mining.  Shame on you NPR for goose-stepping to the technological drum-beat!!

title: The fastest way to catch up
comment: This is a great app. I like to start my day by playing the hourly news (which is so convenient), and then I'll look through some articles and audio snippets that I want to know more about. I used to be undisciplined about keeping up, but with this app I can get the essential stories in just a couple of minutes, even while I'm occupied with something else.

title: Cant listen to it
comment: I love NPR but this app is not working on my galaxy s3. It might also be because im in Mexico...not sure. Hopefully it will get fixed so we can all enjoy NPR.
Does not offer landscape mode

title: Use it every day, but its ugly and buggy
comment: I love that this app exists, i.e. I can get my NPR content on my android, but it is ugly and hard to use.  Doing what I do every day (just listening to my local station) takes way too many clicks from the app startup screen.  For a while I didn't even realise I could just listen to live radio, so was clicking on a bunch of stories to add them into a playlist each day.  It doesn't play well with Google maps navigation: every time the navigation cuts in to give a direction you hear another startup advertisement, so I can't use it while I'm driving.  It also doesn't deal well with network changes: if I start playing at my house on my way out it will stop playing when I'm out of range of wifi, despite there being mobile data available.

title: Bad text formatting
comment: In 2013 you'd expect an app to be moveable to storage. Strike 1!  Can't format text correctly? Duh that is a basic function. Strike 2!  Audio doesn't download from links - kinda the point of the app no?  Strike 3 - You're outta here...

title: Buggy
comment: Iive stream keeps cutting out!
love NPR!

title: Not for tablets

title: Doesn't work...crashes

title: Inconsistent and poorly designed -- An after thought
comment: Some days this app works well. Other days it doesn’t work at all. And sometimes it works and then cuts out and then works again. NPR clearly puts more money and time into their iOS app than they do into this tired old thing.  UPDATE: A year later and NPR has made no meaningful changes to this app.

title: Great access to NPR content!

title: I love widgets

title: Frustrating and terrible
comment: Please fire the people responsible for this app.  I listen to Morning Edition and All Things Considered via this app when I can't catch it on the radio. Half of the stories are a-ok, but the other half are cut in half when you only hear the tail end of the story, and sometimes the beginning shows up later on in the program.  This is totally inexcusable, if you ask me. Downloading and playing an audio clip is not a complicated technological feat, and the fact that this app fails at this is just stupid.  I should note that I've used the NPR app on iPhone and Android, back and forth since about 2008 and these problems have been persistent throughout this time period.

title: Crash... reinstall... crash!

I do listen to NPR while traveling to and from cities while in my vehicle. I find the programs and news more informative.  By the time I'm home I will have more details about an issue that I see on the evening news channels.

I'd love to be able to catch up on past programs on the Samsung while driving to work, but this app won't let me do that.

title: Top-notch journalism; needs interface improvements
comment: NPR is my go-to source of information when it comes to journalism in the US. The only other app I currently bother using for news is BBC. I love how organized the app is, and how it has several features that make it easy to consume the many various aspects of NPR, such as listening to certain shows, finding your favorite station, listening to/reading stories by your preferred category, and the ability to share. However, I feel that there is room for improvement. Each story in the queue takes up quite a lot of space on the screen with a great deal of dead space for each line. Maybe this is good for users with poorer vision, but I prefer to have more content on my screen so I don't have to do as much scrolling. I'm also not especially fond of the audio bar at the bottom of the screen, as it takes up as much real estate as one news item. If it were consolidated to the top of the screen, I could browse more stories instead of essentially having a giant button. Lastly, I wouldn't mind spending a few dollars for this app if it meant eliminating advertisements at the bottom of the screen. Aside from these complaints, I'm quite happy with NPR's mobile app. Keep up the excellent journalism!

title: Underwhemling

And I have noticed the same issue on both platforms: The audio just stops working, and refuses to play stories, over and over again, no matter how many times you restart the app. The app is okay for reading stories or live-streaming stations, but the "playlist" feature is basically useless. I can't tell you how frustrating that is. I love NPR, especially for their content. But what the hell is going on with your app, NPR? FIX IT.

title: One step forward, two steps back
comment: The UI is nicer now, but the app is no more stable. It still crashes, and now stories routinely have their text "layered" in a way that makes them scrambled and illegible. It also randomly will refuse to play audio after playing only one story. Two stars only for the quality of the stories (when they will actually play).

I hate to complain about a free app from free public radio but this app is pretty bad. I am using it on my month and half old Google Nexus 4 and there are several things wrong with it. While streaming my local station, it will often lose connection and go silent and I will need to come back to the phone and hit the play button again or even sometimes restart the app entirely. Somehow my favorite stations will disappear from the list. The widget will not play my local station's stream without first opening the app and hitting play from within the app. What's the point of the widget then? And finally there's the playlist problems. For example, I will add all of the clips from the show 'Wait Wait... Don't Tell Me' and it will sometimes duplicate one of the clips. While playing the clips it will skip over clips and sometimes will start playing clips not from the beginning like it should but from one or two minutes into the clip. I hope all of these issues can be resolved. I do love NPR!

title: Identified a playlist issue
comment: First of all, great app!  Still a few issues, but for the most part, now that I have learned how to manipulate it to avoid the pitfalls, it works flawlessly most of the time.  I can definitely understand the frustration out there though.  Here is an issue I have positively identified:  When the playlist contains a story that is shorter in length than the next story, the second story will begin playing where the first one left off, cutting off the beginning (or indeed sometimes MOST OF) the next story.  So, if story1 is 3:02, and story2 is 4:25, story 2 will begin playing at 3:03.  I imagine that would be easy to fix with an additional check at the beginning of the process of moving to the next story.  Another item that happens, and I don't know why, but I suspect it may have to do with audio availability: when looking at a programs' stories, if it is at or near the beginning of the playtime on the first stations to run the story, the app sometimes crashes.  Third item:  when streaming, app will turn itself off 5 minutes after starting the stream.  Could this be the result of the previous story's playtime being reached?  Keep up the good work!

title: Fix this app please

title: How can worst app be favorite app?
comment: This is, by far, the worst app I still use regularly. NPR is great, and this app is the best way to consume NPR. I never listen to my local station anymore (not even when in the car). This app makes the broadcast format as obsolescent as the internet does for dead-tree content.  But the app itself is terrible. The design is a bit quirky but serviceable. The problem is mainly it is BUGGY as all get-out. I have used this app for 2+ years, on 4 different Android phones, on equally as many versions of Android, on wif-fi and on mobile data. So it is definitely not merely an isolated "fragmentation" issue. It is the app itself. I experience the following problems, at a frequency of probably 1 per 15 minutes:  - New story starts mid-stream - App freezes for 15-60 seconds, then starts playing (not buffering, app itself is frozen) - App force closes  There have been many updates, but none have improved reliability perceptibly.  I would definitely pay to get a better app. 99% of the time I love that NPR is blissfully free from commercial pressures. This is one exception--no for-profit company with competition would let such a high-potential product langusih this way. :(

title: Downloads for offline listening?????
comment: This app really needs the ability to download podcasts for offline listening.  I'm trying to replace Google Listen, which is now defunct, and I really miss the ability to download a podcast for future listening.  I like to setup my playlist and download all the shows so I can listen to them later while I'm on the go.  If I am out and about somewhere with limited service, this app is unusable.  It's going to be even more important to be able to download via Wi-Fi for later consumption as the wireless carriers move away from unlimited data plans.  Seems like a pretty basic feature that is missing in action.

title: Better but still buggy
comment: I went from one to three stars because the stability of this app has improved...a bit. I've had this on three different phones from two different carriers so I'm pretty certain that the issues I've had with this app aren't hardware or network related. Freezes; it doesn't as often happen as often on my HTC Evo 3D but it still happens. I also get skips when one story finishes and then when the next in the playlist plays (and there is usually a sometimes very long wait for the next story to play) very often most of the next story has been skipped. I only get the final 30 seconds of that story. I've also found that when the app is interrupted by and incoming call, whether that call is taken or rejected, the sound through my bluetooth device (headphones, car audio) from the app is gone. While other apps are able to play through bluetooth audio, NPR is silent and can't access bluetooth audio until the phone is rebooted. I realize that building an app that has to work on multiple different hardware, software and networks options is a challenge but most other developers seem to be doing a much better job getting this done than those who have designed with app.

Pausing for a phone call makes sense but shouldn't pause for any other things. Would love to see simple stop/ play controls in the sticky notification on ICS.

I really hope the next update will address these problems.

title: App crashes when my notifications bar updates
comment: As a general rule, the app works great.  But there are two exceptions, on my G2:  1. When I am listening to a live stream, and I get a notification in my notifications bar (e.g., a new email), the app quits playing for a moment so that I can get the audio notification, and disappears from my notifications bar, because the notifications bar is temporarily reserved for the new notification.  But when the new notification fades and the regular notification bar returns, the NPR app appears for only a second before disappearing entirely, and the app never begins playing the news again.  If I am still on the app, then I can easily restart the stream by unlocking my phone and pressing "play" again, but I shouldn't have to work this hard for it.  2. When I switch from wifi to 4G, it takes the phone a moment to find the 4G data stream.  If I activate the app before the phone finds the 4G data stream, and choose to look at my Favorite Stations, clicking on one of my Favorite Stations does not take me to that page; instead, it removes my favorite station from the list, and I have to search for it and re-add it again.  This is annoying.  Please fix these bugs!

title: Great Content, Horribly Buggy App
comment: I give up. I've been trying to use this app for a long time--NPR's programing is really compelling--but this app is so buggy that I end up frustrated almost every time I try using it. The sorts of bugs I'm talking about: freezing up... and then suddenly starting playing again 10 minutes later, when you've moved on to something else; unpredictably starting programs in the middle instead of the beginning; and freaking out if you move between WiFi and cellular connectivity during a program. It's also missing the single most obvious feature it should have: you can't pre-load programs to listen to when you don't have an internet connection. Further, it doesn't even try to start loading a program until the previous one is completely finished--so you get a gap between programs who'se length depends on the quality of your connection. These could be forgiven in a new app... but this app has been out for years and the only updates it's received have made it noticeably *more* buggy (in fairness, they did give us a great new feature, though: in-app ads...). Come on, NPR, fix this thing so your content has an app deserving of it! [Droid, Nexus One, Nexus S, and Galaxy Nexus]

title: Useless, unless you never have data problems
comment: (A reminder: Public Radio costs money to run, and you depend on it or you wouldn't be reading this. So support your local NPR station, even though the network releases crap software like this.)  This is a fact: phone data connections flake out. Radio shadows, not enough cell towers, bad karma, whatever, you can't assume your data connection works perfectly every single second. And a good mobile streaming app deals with this.  This app does not. Run out of buffer on a live stream, and the app simply resets the stream, meaning you have to listen to the station's opening blurb over and over and over. Run out of buffer on a queued story, and the app simply skips to the next story? What idiot thought that made sense?  To listen to an NPR station on your device, install a generic MP3 streaming client like StreamFurious. If the client doesn't already have your station in its database, go to the station's web site, find the MP3 stream URL, and copy it into the client.  Can't think of a way to queue up NPR stores the way this app does. Too bad, it's a cool feature.

Also, it keeps trying to start my gps app.  I just got rid of it, end of troubles until they decide to fix it.  Alternative, try looking for individual station apps. Some stations have them & they work better than this POS.  April 30, 2012 - The stations that used to work now don't work either.  The app crashed once & hung my phone right after that.  I had to pull the battery to kill it.  Uninstalled for now, waiting for someone to fix this.  I can't believe how apps get released with no testing.  I wrote computer programs as a living for many years.  One concept that should be always the same is to test changes before releasing them!

title: Could be great
comment: I am a HUGE NPR fan, so this was among the first apps that I got. If your local NPR affiliate doesn't carry your preferred programming, this is a great option. For that reason, I want to love this app, but I can't.   GOOD:   1) selection of programs and podcasts;   2) you can create a playlist;  3) you can listen live;  4) many program episode lists are archived so you can listen to programs that are "older";  5) multiple searches;  6) you can program radio presets. I assume this lets you listen in your car via BlueTooth.  BAD:  1) some programs have only that day's episodes, so you can easily miss out;  2) the "clear list/played" buttons are badly placed so that it's easy to delete programs before you intend to. This is particularly frustrating given #1;  3) I can't fast forward on my phone. There is a slide bar and I can do this on my tablet;  UGLY:  1) the app force closes A LOT;  2) there's no QUIT button so it runs in the background even after you stop it.Sometimes it will restart itself if I don't close through TaskManager.  I want to love it, but I can't. This NPR member isn't impressed. Hoping for improvements in future updates. Samsung Galaxy S Vibrant

title: Buggy and no "exit" button
comment: I'm only rating it a 2 to be nice.  While it's free, my expectations should be low but if NPR wants to increase its listener base, they need to throw a few more $ towards making a stable app.  It seems to know to cut out whenever I'm particularly interested in the topic of discussion, of course.  I use several other audio streaming apps and they only cut out when signal is weak - the NPR app cuts out randomly and frequently regardless of signal strength.    Also, I would like to have a simple "exit" or off button.  The lack thereof makes it a multi-step process to sign out of the app - to shut it down entirely I have to click the PAUSE button to stop it playing, back out through all of the screens to exit, then kill it through the app-killer.  This is a silly pain and it makes me only listen when a particularly important show is on.  I might use it more frequently if it was easier and worked better.
